abstract: Material production, and associated carbon emissions, could be reduced by reusing products instead of landfilling or recycling them. Steel beams are well suited to reuse, but are difficult to reuse when connected compositely to concrete slabs using welded studs. A demountable connection would allow composite performance but also permit reuse of both components at end-of-life. Three composite beams, of 2 m, 10 m and 5 m length, are constructed using M20 bolts as demountable shear connectors. The beams are tested in three-, six- and four-point bending, respectively. The former two are loaded to service, unloaded, demounted and reassembled; all three are tested to failure. The results show that all three have higher strengths than predicted using Eurocode 4. The longer specimens have performance similar to previously published comparable welded-connector composite beam results. This suggests that demountable composite beams can be safely used and practically reused, thus reducing carbon emissions. © 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

author_highlights.sentence: Three composite beams were constructed with a novel, demountable shear connector.
Moment capacities were greater than predictions made using Eurocode 4-1-1.
Results were compared with those for similar beams with welded studs.
Beam performance was similar with welded and demountable studs.

body_text.sentence: Fig. 5 shows the arrangement of the 10 m specimen, mimicking Hicks' [11] setup: 7 pairs of bolts in one half-span and 15 single bolts (staggered either side of the web to ensure even application of force) in the other; 2.5 m wide slab cast from C16/20 concrete, 140 mm thick on the decking.
body_text.title: Laboratory testing of demountable connector design in 10m specimen

body_text.sentence: Results from the material tests for the 2 m specimen are given in Table 1.
body_text.title: 2m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Both beams fail due to concrete pull-out in the left half-span (i.e. with stud pairs) at similar moment values.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Most papers to date have examined welded connectors.
body_text.title: Review of published literature

body_text.sentence: The 5 m specimen's ultimate moment capacity remains above predicted values (and almost 50% greater than the plastic moment capacity of the steel beam alone) despite the initial damage, indicating that sufficient shear connection remained.
body_text.title: Comparison of results with predictions and with welded specimens

body_text.sentence: Site welding also involves extra health & safety risks that are avoided when bolting.
body_text.title: Implementation of demountable composite beams in industry

body_text.sentence: Maximum end-slips of 13.3 mm (left side) and 12.0 mm (right side) were recorded — similar to the 12.9 mm of slip Hicks [11] reports for first failure.
body_text.title: 5m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Size M20 was chosen as similar to the 19 mm welded studs that Hicks used.
body_text.title: Avenues for further research

body_text.sentence: Midspan deflection was increased to 490 mm, causing a moment of 434 kNm (14% higher than the predicted maximum) but without causing failure in the right half-span — at this point it was noticed that the end-stop itself had failed and the experiment halted.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: The divergence for the 5 m specimens can potentially be explained by the larger strains imposed during the 10 m testing — Hicks' [11] 5 m specimen saw 100 mm less midspan deflection when still part of the 10 m specimen.
body_text.title: Comparison of results with predictions and with welded specimens

body_text.sentence: After testing was complete longitudinal cracks were noticed along the centreline of the slab, further indicating concrete failure initiated at the bolt locations.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Both curves exhibit elastic behaviour initially followed by a ductile plateau, caused by formation of a plastic hinge in the beam approximately under the point-load immediately left of midspan, revealed by Lüder's wedges visible in the web and confirmed by strain gauge readings.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: The 10 m specimen was successfully loaded to service, demounted and reassembled; the latter two processes were achieved more easily and quickly than had been anticipated.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Eurocode 4-1-1 [10] calculations with these values predict failure of the concrete at the stud pairs at a moment of 357 kNm, 5% less than the maximum moment (including self-weight) recorded experimentally: 378 kNm.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Although both 10 m specimens failed in similar ways, the results from Section 4.2 exceed predictions whereas Hicks' [11] result was lower than expected.
body_text.title: Comparison of results with predictions and with welded specimens

parents.title: Methodology to test a demountable connector design

body_text.sentence: The slab was then lowered and beam reattached.
body_text.title: Laboratory testing of demountable connector design in 10m specimen

body_text.sentence: The reality of using bolted connectors on commercial projects is explored, finding two challenges and two potential solutions.
body_text.title: Discussion of implications of results

body_text.sentence: The 2 m specimen was successfully demounted and reassembled.
body_text.title: 2m specimen results

body_text.sentence: However there are additional challenges in handling and verifying such re-used slabs, and further examination of this opportunity is required.
body_text.title: Further challenges and policy recommendations

body_text.sentence: Knowledge about demountable connectors could be increased in three ways: producing tailored design guidance, creating an analytical model of internal interaction, and performing push tests.
body_text.title: Avenues for further research

body_text.sentence: An analytical model could be developed to predict these internal forces and compared with experimental results — Lee and Bradford's [26] work could potentially be extended to include this.
body_text.title: Avenues for further research

body_text.sentence: Using demountable connectors could allow extra flexibility in the finished building as the steel beam can be replaced if the concrete were propped.
body_text.title: Implementation of demountable composite beams in industry

body_text.sentence: The moment capacities of the 10 m and 5 m specimens are 2% and 12% lower than those from Hicks' [11] specimens using welded studs.
body_text.title: Comparison of results with predictions and with welded specimens

body_text.sentence: These larger strains probably invalidated the ‘unfailed’ assumption about the 5 m specimen, as shown by the strain gauge failures and the different failure sequence than that reported by Hicks [11].
body_text.title: Comparison of results with predictions and with welded specimens

body_text.sentence: To give confidence to designers when considering bolted connectors, tailored design guidance is required to provide formulae and empirical values suited for demountable connectors because formulae and empirical factors in current guidance, e.g. Eurocode 4-1-1 [10], assume welded studs.
body_text.title: Avenues for further research

body_text.sentence: Over time an increasing number of failure modes have been identified from push tests: Hawkins & Mitchell [15] describe four (stud shear, concrete pull-out, rib shear, rib punching), Johnson & Yuan [19] identify three more (splitting failure and two combination modes) and Patrick [20] classifies four additional, less common modes.
body_text.title: Review of literature on traditional, welded-connector composite beams

body_text.sentence: Every year 1500 million tonnes of steel are produced worldwide [1].
body_text.title: Introduction: the opportunity to reduce carbon emissions by reusing composite structures

body_text.sentence: Inspection of the slab once the decking had been removed confirmed concrete pull-out failure around the bolts.
body_text.title: 5m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Dallam [23] and Marshall et al. [24] performed tests in the 1960s investigating the behaviour of friction-grip bolts as composite connectors but focused on the effect of pre-tensioning on the connection and did not demount them.
body_text.title: Review of literature on demountable connectors

body_text.sentence: Eurocode 4-1-1 [10] calculations performed using this value and other properties taken from Table 2 predicted failure of the concrete at the studs at a moment of 328 kNm; 13% lower than that found experimentally.
body_text.title: 5m specimen results

body_text.sentence: The steel beam can be predrilled with holes for the bolts as part of the automated fabrication process to ensure a good fit, requiring only one person to tighten the nuts from below.
body_text.title: Implementation of demountable composite beams in industry

body_text.sentence: This is expected because design standards such as Eurocode deliberately predict conservatively to allow for uncertainties.
body_text.title: Comparison of results with predictions and with welded specimens

body_text.sentence: Bolt slips, as measured at the underside of the flange, were nowhere more than 2 mm.
body_text.title: 2m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Accounting for these two effects, the 5 m specimen's moment capacity is still 3% lower than Hicks' value; however the 10 m specimen's capacity is 8% higher.
body_text.title: Comparison of results with predictions and with welded specimens

body_text.sentence: Research is needed to inform the optimal material properties and geometry for connectors, accounting for ductility as well as strength, and considering that standard practice uses higher-strength concrete.
body_text.title: Avenues for further research

parents.title: Methodology to test a demountable connector design

body_text.sentence: Strain gauges were affixed longitudinally at the centre of the flanges and at 45° to the vertical on the web at 15 locations indicated in Fig. 5.
body_text.title: Laboratory testing of demountable connector design in 10m specimen

body_text.sentence: Design guidance has been continually updated to incorporate developments in understanding and research.
body_text.title: Review of literature on traditional, welded-connector composite beams

body_text.sentence: Concrete cube and cylinder tests undertaken the same day the specimen failed (68 days after casting) resulted in a characteristic cylinder compression strength of 11.1 MPa.
body_text.title: 5m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Greater computing power has allowed increasingly detailed modelling of beam and connector behaviour: Johnson & Molenstra [16] input a mathematical model from first principles to calculate strength and slip, while Ellobody & Young [17] and Qureshi & Lam [18] create finite element models to do the same; such models are still validated against push test results however.
body_text.title: Review of literature on traditional, welded-connector composite beams

body_text.sentence: A failure moment of 248 kNm was calculated from the back-analysis of strains; this is within 1% of the experimental value.
body_text.title: 2m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Fig. 12 shows the moment-displacement graph at the midspan of the specimen, with self-weight moment and predicted failure moments from Eurocode 4-1-1 [10] indicated.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: While the technology now exists to demount and reuse steel beams, hence reducing carbon dioxide emissions associated with new material production, there is as yet no demand for this option.
body_text.title: Further challenges and policy recommendations

body_text.sentence: Policy recommendations are needed to encourage adaptation of demountable and reusable systems in construction.
body_text.title: Discussion of implications of results

body_text.sentence: Grade 8.8 bolts (with a nominal ultimate strength of 800 MPa) were used in the present trials, unlike those used by Hicks' [11] whose studs had an ultimate strength of 513 MPa.
body_text.title: Avenues for further research

body_text.sentence: As expected the neutral axis position falls as the slab slips under increasing load.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: The 5 m specimen (shown in Fig. 17a) was loaded in cycles until deck delamination occurred (shown in Fig. 17b) in the right half-span of the beam – where bolts were in the ‘favourable’ position (as indicated in Fig. 6) – at a maximum moment of 376 kNm and midspan deflection of 145 mm.
body_text.title: 5m specimen results

body_text.sentence: However, commercially-designed composite beams would typically have higher shear connection resulting in the neutral axis being closer to the flange and reducing the loss in moment capacity, in which case the benefit of having smaller holes may be negligible.
body_text.title: Avenues for further research

body_text.sentence: In conference papers, Lee and Bradford [26] develop a ‘quasi-elastic mechanics based’ theoretical model for the behaviour of pre-tensioned bolts and validate it against push test results, while Lam & Saveri [27] describe experiments using connectors machined from traditional studs with threads (shown in Fig. 1) so they can be bolted onto a beam and disassembled.
body_text.title: Review of literature on demountable connectors

body_text.sentence: To compare connector performance with that of welded studs, the larger specimens were constructed to the same specifications as Hicks' [11], who undertook tests on 10 m and 5 m specimens with welded studs in the same laboratory in 2005.
body_text.title: Methodology to test a demountable connector design

body_text.sentence: Fig. 15 displays a plot of midspan moment against the slip of four bolts (as measured at the lower nut) taken from different locations along the beam (labelled on Fig. 5).
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: A shear force of approx. 5 kN is needed to overcome the friction induced by the torque on each bolt; this may explain the small initial gradient to each plot.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: However push tests by Lam and Saveri [27] and Lee and Bradford [26] indicate that demountable studs perform better than welded studs in such tests anyway.
body_text.title: Avenues for further research

body_text.sentence: Responding to these claims, Hicks [11] performed 6 push tests and 2 beam-bending tests and showed that the two sets of results have a poor correlation.
body_text.title: Review of literature on traditional, welded-connector composite beams

body_text.sentence: Fig. 7b shows the demounted beam below the suspended slab, contrasted with the initial configuration in Fig. 7a.
body_text.title: 2m specimen results

body_text.sentence: Fig. 10 shows the test specimen in initial and disassembled states.
body_text.title: 10m specimen results

body_text.sentence: The nuts may become difficult to remove after 20 years in place or may damage their bond with the concrete in doing so — so further research is required to understand changes in bolt condition over time.
body_text.title: Implementation of demountable composite beams in industry
